Situation1: They occasionally tidy up visible clutter and do light cleaning in shared spaces.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: I glance at the clock as I wipe down the kitchen counter, crumbs scattering under my cloth. The living room still needs vacuuming, and the bathroom mirror is streaked with toothpaste. My supervisor expects every surface to shine, even though most of my coworkers only do a quick sweep and call it a day. I want to do my job right, to leave the house spotless, but my phone buzzes with a reminder: the community study circle meets in an hour. Tonight, we’re discussing verses from the Quran I haven’t had time to read, let alone reflect on. I know the group expects me to participate, to share insights and show my commitment to our faith. My heart aches with guilt—if I rush my cleaning, I’ll fall short of my standards; if I stay late, I’ll walk into the study circle unprepared, feeling like an outsider. The mop handle feels heavy in my hand as I stand in the hallway, torn between the demands of my work and the expectations of my faith, unsure which responsibility I should honor first.
